sect1.title: What's New For Administrators
sect1.para: As of GNOME 2.14, the GNOME Project now includes the GNOME Administration Suite, a collection of tools that are aimed squarely at systems administrators. The two new tools that form the beginnings of this suite are incredibly powerful and should help administrators in both large corporate deployments and situations where machine lockdown is required.

sect2.title: Sabayon - Profile Editor
sect2.para: Sabayon allows administrators to set up user profiles inside a live, interactive GNOME session. When the administrator chooses to create or edit a profile, a nested GNOME session is started up that the administrator can use to change anything they could change in their own GNOME session.

textobject.phrase: Using Sabayon to edit a user profile in an embedded window

sect2.para: Sabayon will track changes to both files and GConf settings. The administrator can then choose to remove accidental changes or make other changes mandatory rather than optional (eg. lockdown settings or proxy settings). Once complete, the administrator can package up these profiles and deploy them to machines.

Users or groups (???) are placed into profiles which will be used when they log into their GNOME session. Being able to easily create multiple profiles and allocate each user separately allows users to have different setups based on their job description (eg. receptionist, data entry clerk, programmer, human resources manager, etc.).

sect2.title: Pessulus - Lockdown Editor
sect2.para: Pessulus is a lockdown editor that allows administrators of corporate environments, Internet cafes and other computing environments to disable certain features of the GNOME desktop.

figure.title: Using the lockdown editor to prevent system shutdown by users

sect2.para: Some features that can be disabled included:

listitem.para: the ability to shutdown or reboot a machine; and
the ability to edit the GNOME panels.
